Introduction

Mycoplasma genitalium is a sexually transmitted bacterium that can infect the genital and urinary tracts as well as the rectum.  It is a small, self-replicating organism belonging to the class Mollicutes.  Like other types of mycoplasma bacteria (eg, M pneumonia, Ureaplasma urealyticum), M genitalium lacks a cell wall, making it difficult to culture, stain, and treat.  Although M genitalium infection is often asymptomatic, it is a common cause of cervicitis in females and nongonococcal urethritis in males.

Pathogenesis



M genitalium has a specialized terminal tip-like structure that allows it to attach and adhere to the surfaces of cells.  This structure allows the bacterium to move along host surfaces and penetrate into tissues (ie, invasion).  After invasion, M genitalium alters the expression of its surface proteins, allowing it to avoid immune detection and persist in the host.  Host tissue destruction from the secretion of mycoplasmal toxins leads to the chronic inflammation and tissue damage responsible for most of the clinical disease manifestations.  Because the bacterium can form biofilms, which are protective clusters of bacteria encased in a polysaccharide matrix, M genitalium is protected from immune responses and antibiotic treatments, facilitating chronic infection.

Risk factors



The most important risk factor in the spread of M genitalium infection is high-risk sexual activity.  There is an increased risk of infection with unprotected sexual contact, a new sexual partner, multiple partners, and for men who have sex with men (MSM).  In addition, HIV infection or a prior sexually transmitted infection increases the risk for infection.  Concurrent infection with other sexually transmitted infections, such as chlamydia or gonorrhea, is common and can facilitate the transmission and persistence of M genitalium.

Clinical presentations

Male urogenital infection



  • Urethritis:  A leading cause of nongonococcal urethritis, infection of the urethra by M genitalium is frequently asymptomatic but may cause urethral discharge, pruritus, and dysuria.
  • Prostatitis (
    figure 1
    ):  More common in MSM, infection of the prostate can cause fever, pelvic and perineal pain, dysuria, and obstructive voiding symptoms (eg, hesitancy, dribbling).

Female urogenital infection



  • Cervicitis (
    figure 2
    ):  Cervical infection is most commonly asymptomatic.  When symptomatic, patients often have purulent or mucopurulent cervical discharge and intermenstrual or postcoital bleeding.
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) (
    figure 3
    ):  PID is a polymicrobial infection of the upper genital tract (ie, uterus, fallopian tubes, ovaries).  PID causes pelvic or abdominal pain that may be accompanied by fever, abnormal uterine bleeding, and mucopurulent cervical discharge.  More severe cases can lead to tuboovarian abscess, Fitz-Hugh and Curtis syndrome (inflammation of the Glisson capsule surrounding the liver), and sepsis.  PID leads to scarring of the fallopian tubes and an increased risk for infertility and ectopic pregnancy.
  • Reproductive complications:  Infection can increase the risk of preterm delivery and spontaneous abortion.

Extragenital Infection



  • Proctitis:  Inflammation of the rectum is more common in MSM, especially those who are HIV-positive.  Symptoms include anal itching, discharge, and pain during bowel movements.


The organism does not commonly spread throughout the body, and infections beyond the anogenital area have been reported only in rare cases.

Diagnosis and laboratory evaluation



Nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) is the preferred method for diagnosing M genitalium.  This is because M genitalium is extremely difficult to grow in the laboratory setting, a process that may take up to 6 months to complete.  NAAT bypasses the need for culture, allowing for quicker and more practical diagnosis.  Some NAATs also evaluate for antibiotic resistance mutations, especially macrolide resistance, which impacts treatment strategy.



In male patients, NAAT can be performed on a first-catch urine specimen or urethral swab.  In female patients, NAAT performed on a vaginal or endocervical swab is preferred, but it can also be performed on a first-catch urine specimen.  NAAT can also be performed on rectal swabs if indicated by sexual activity or symptoms.  Routine panels for sexually transmitted infections often do not include M genitalium unless specifically requested.  Therefore, it should be considered in symptomatic patients who test negative for chlamydia and gonorrhea.

Treatment



Treatment is complicated by increased antimicrobial resistance, particularly to macrolides and fluoroquinolones.  Because M genitalium lacks a cell wall, beta-lactam antibiotics (eg, penicillins, cephalosporins) are ineffective.  Furthermore, due to increasing macrolide resistance, 2-stage therapy approaches, ideally using resistance-guided therapy, are recommended for treatment.



First-line treatment (if macrolide susceptibility is known) is with a course of oral doxycycline followed by an extended regimen of azithromycin.  If macrolide resistance is unknown or if resistance is confirmed, treatment is with a course of doxycycline followed by a course of moxifloxacin.



A test of cure is not recommended unless there are persistent symptoms or concerns for unidentified resistance.

Prevention



The most effective means of prevention is with safe sex practices (eg, consistent condom use) and expedited partner notification and treatment (to prevent reinfection and further transmission).

Prognosis



For most uncomplicated infections, prompt treatment usually results in a good prognosis.  In female patients, M genitalium infection can lead to PID, which can have permanent consequences such as chronic pelvic pain, infertility, and tubal damage that can predispose to ectopic pregnancy.  Serious complications of PID, such as tuboovarian abscess and sepsis, can be fatal.



In addition, pregnancies complicated by maternal M genitalium infection are at increased risk for preterm delivery and subsequent complications of prematurity (eg, respiratory distress, cerebral palsy).

Summary



M genitalium is a significant cause of urethritis in men and cervicitis and PID in women.  Its small genome and lack of a cell wall make it unique among bacterial pathogens, contributing to its resilience and difficulty in treatment.  Due to increasing resistance, especially to macrolides, careful antimicrobial selection guided by susceptibility testing is critical.
